newsitem.title: TURKEY: Formation of brokerages by Turk banks seen positive.
newsitem.headline: Formation of brokerages by Turk banks seen positive.

text.p: Turkish brokers say the formation of separate brokerage houses by banks to carry out all capital market activities under a new regulation by the Capital Market Board (SPK), is necessary for stock market development.
Senior bank and brokerage officials told Reuters that separating capital market activities from banking activities might have positive outcomes such as establishing a "qualified" intermediary sector.

"It is hard for small brokerage houses which do not have many customers and a research and development departments, to survive from now on. The market needs more powerful, big brokerage houses," said Atilla Koksal, assistant general manager in Interbank.

SPK obliged the Istanbul Stock Exchange's (ISE) 62 member banks to set up new or acquire existing brokerage houses with a minimum 125 billion lira capital till January 2, 1997 to carry on their capital markets activities separately.

"The capital markets department will be able to express itself better after being separated from the bank. It is hard to perform investment banking adeguately together with (regular) banking," said Cengiz Bicer, assistant general manager in Sumerbank.
So far, eight banks have officially disclosed their intention to form new brokerage houses.

SPK recommended banks to apply until November 11 for approval to set up a new brokerage, but said futures applications by banks that are not currently interested in setting up or buying a brokerage, would also be considered after January 2.

The intermediary licenses of a bank which does not set up or buy a brokerage house will be cancelled, except the ones to make T-bill repurchase and reverse repurchase deals in the Exchange's bond market and broker share trade outside the Exchange.
Separation from banks will enable brokerage performances to be measured adequately, said Erol Goker, general manager of Turkey's leading Global securities.

"Everyone will see that (brokerage) business is very profitable indeed. Thus, banks will invest more (in the capital markets) and this will affect the development of the capital markets positively," he said.
A bank's brokerage will not be able to carry the word "bank" in its title. Its ownership may be divided between the bank and other financial firms within the group controlling the bank.
Goker said the setting up of brokerages by banks would also help to build trust in the stock market.
"The inequality between brokerage houses and banks, arising from banks being under the guarantee of the state, will be omitted," he said.
Stock market tansactions of the banks totalled 1,190 trillion lira while those of the brokerage houses were 2,570 trillion lira in January-September this year.
The brokerage houses made a total of 1,950 trillion lira volume in the bond market while banks made 55,600 trillion lira in the same period.
